title: 106_hr3165
content: Section 301(a) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. Super Majority Requirement amendments are made to sections 904(c)(1) and 904(d)(2) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a Point of Order to Protect Medicare, preventing any budget resolution that would decrease the on-budget surplus below the level of the medicare surplus reserve for fiscal years 2000 through 2009. This does not apply to legislation appropriating funds for prescription drug benefits. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include a Point of Order to Protect Medicare, preventing any budget resolution that would decrease the on-budget surplus below the level of the medicare surplus reserve for fiscal years 2000 through 2009. This does not apply to legislation appropriating funds for prescription drug benefits under the Medicare program. Interest costs would decrease the on-budget surplus below the level of the medicare surplus reserve for fiscal years 2000 through 2009, except for legislation appropriating funds for prescription drug benefits under the Medicare program. The text discusses amending the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to define the term 'Medicare surplus reserve' as \1/3\ of any on-budget surplus for fiscal years 2000 through 2009. It also includes changes to the super majority requirement in the Act. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF DISCRETIONARY SPENDING LIMITS. Extension of Limits and Amounts under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 are amended, extending the limits to 2014 and adjusting the amounts for various categories for fiscal year 2000. In fiscal years 2001, 2002, and 2003, there were significant amounts allocated for budget authority and outlays in various categories such as discretionary, highway, and mass transit. In fiscal years 2003 to 2006, significant amounts were allocated for budget authority and outlays in the discretionary, highway, and mass transit categories. In fiscal years 2007 to 2009, the discretionary category had allocated budget authority and outlays as follows: $644,525,000,000 and $687,532,000,000 in 2007, $663,611,000,000 and $704,534,000,000 in 2008, and $678,019,000,000 and $721,215,000,000 in 2009, respectively. SEC. 7. Extension and clarification of pay-as-you-go requirement. Section 252 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to change dates and include provisions for surplus decreases. Amend section 252 to include provisions for surplus decreases by adding "or Surplus" after "Deficit Increase" in subsection (c). SEC. 8 amends the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act to extend deadlines to September 30, 2014 and 2018. SEC. 9 extends the Social Security firewall in the Congressional Budget Act to September 30, 2014. SEC. 10 protects Social Security interest savings transfers. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act is amended to include "surplus" and "deficit". Legislation that affects Social Security transfers will not be counted as a pay-as-you-go offset. Conforming changes are also made. The Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions that reduce, reverse, or repeal transfers under section 201(n) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 11. CONFORMING CHANGES. Section 254 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions for surplus, deficit, and deficit increase. Section 258A is also amended to address surplus increase, and Section 258(C) is amended for process changes. The Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include provisions for surplus increase in various paragraphs.
